Last mile delivery — it’s one of the most important aspects of the delivery timeline, if not the most important. But last mile delivery isn’t literally the last mile before delivery, rather, it’s the movement of goods from the transportation hub to the final delivery destination.

Think of last mile delivery as the home stretch — the final delivery service that brings the goods from the fulfillment center to the customer. That could be 2 blocks or 200 miles.

Despite being an important part of the transportation process, it’s often the most misunderstood part of transportation networks and is plagued with issues. On the surface, this likely doesn’t seem like a big deal. But in reality, it can dramatically affect a delivery services’ logistics, alter cost(last mile delivery can make up about 28 percent of a shipments total cost), and even dramatically affect e-commerce.

So, what’s the best way to solve these last mile challenges?

First, take the time to understand them. As our modern-day society continues to grow and offers us the technology to solve our delivery issues, we must first emphasize understanding and studying the issues so we can properly utilize that technology.

We’ve listed out the top five last mile challenges that delivery companies face. But more than that, we’ve included a few creative solutions and suggestions for solving these issues.

Check out the top five last mile problems — and their solutions — below!

Challenge No 1: Incomplete Delivery

Incomplete deliveries area common problem for last mile delivery services. Whether this means that the courier was given the wrong address, there was a snag in traffic, or an unforeseen circumstance, the general idea behind an incomplete delivery is that the parcel simply didn’t make it to its final destination.

Solution

While there are infinite possibilities for unforeseen circumstances that could disrupt a last mile delivery, planning ahead can work wonders for last mile delivery services. Consider using a route planning software to help you strategize and plan ahead so that you can avoid incomplete deliveries. According to Metrobi, by implementing route planning software, companies that use route optimization software have a 65 percent higher customer satisfaction rate. The greatest things about these types of software? They’re customizable and adaptable, changing your route plan based on order cancellations, weather, traffic conditions, and more.

Challenge No 2: Late Delivery

Late deliveries are another common problem for last mile delivery services. Any number of things could create a delay and interrupt your schedule, but the reality is, even if the delay isn’t directly your fault, it could result in an irritated customer.

In our fast-paced world, customers expect same-day delivery or next-day delivery — this is a much more commonly accepted frame of time for deliveries. Interrupting that expectation tends to result in an irate customer.

Solution

Transparency and communication are the keys to ensuring your customers are continually satisfied. The reality of the situation is that delays happen — while some are avoidable, there are times where you can’t do a thing to solve them. Allowing them the ability to track the order (and offering honest communication about their deliveries, which will be mentioned in the next section) can keep them calm and rationale. Another way to solve this issue is to stick with the route planning method — this helps avoid (most types of) delays and complications.

Challenge No 3: Transparency

The very basics of customer service within the delivery industry are simple — you have a customer who orders a package and expects it by a certain time; you, as the delivery company handling the last mile delivery are expected to deliver that package on time. Obviously, this doesn’t always happen — there are delays, unexpected circumstances, and more that could disrupt that timeline. But what customers really want — more than anything — is their courier services to be transparent. They want the ability to track their packages and updates in real time. This is not always something courier companies offer.

Solution

The easiest way to solve this issue, theoretically, is to provide customers with real-time, GPS tracking options that allow full transparency and disclosure about where their packages actually are and when they can expect them. Another interesting solution? Allowing customers the option to have 100 percent control on choosing their preferred delivery date and time to avoid complications with handing off packages.

Challenge No 4: Shipping Cost

In an ideal world, retailers would find a delivery service that’s both fast and affordable — but that’s not always the case. Typically, businesses (especially e-commerce companies) are pressured to compete with bigger companies (who have more money to spend on delivery services). In other words, most retailers can’t offer low shipping costs and fast delivery service, which often is reflected in their shipping costs (as a note, unexpected shipping cost are the no. 1 reason people choose to exit a website with items in their cart).

Solution

A possible solution for shipping costs could be to partner with a courier service and include their shipping costs in your item prices. That way, you’re offering a fixed price to your customers with a built-in shipping rate included.

Challenge No 5: Dishonest Customers

We’ve all dealt with dishonest customers before. You know the type — they might claim they didn’t receive goods, that their shipment was delayed, or that their packages never arrived. While an unsatisfied (though dishonest) customers is never a good thing, these types of customers create a bigger issue — they have the ability to take to the internet and give your company a poor review.

Solution

One of the simplest ways to solve this issue is to require a customer to sign for a package, confirming both that they received it and that it was in excellent condition.

As an international courier, we’re frequently tackling the last mile delivery issues that occur all over the world — particularly the no street address issue (a disruptor in the industry that has been prevalent for decades). We continually strive to not only solve current last mile delivery challenges, but proactively create solutions for new issues that could arise internationally.
